channel.title: Ruby Whirlpool/Bzip2
channel.description: Can anyone point me in the direction of a whirlpool hash and bzip2 gem that is not dependent on native libraries? I really don't want to have to write one for each although a whirlpool hash library wouldn't be as bad as a bzip2 library.

item.title: Ruby Whirlpool/Bzip2
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:5, topic:433786”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=536501.msg3922776#msg3922776 date=1329887309]
all I can say is that there are reasons (at least with whirlpool) that people tend to add native optimization libraries onto them, and looking for one exclusively in ruby is probably just a waste of your time
[/quote]

I have reasons for asking for/writing these libraries or else I wouldn’t have posted a topic.[/quote]Really, Sherlock? I never would have guessed. Funny how that has absolutely nothing to do with my post though, considering it was related to the cons of actually using a pure ruby implementation, instead of your ‘reasons’, which I honestly don’t care to know about.

[quote=“sinisoul, post:9, topic:433786”][quote author=t4 link=topic=536501.msg3922789#msg3922789 date=1329888535]

My web host won’t install the gems I need because of security. Most of my site is done in RoR and I need them for a feature I am adding. I did consider the option of moving to python but I enjoy RoR and do not want to redo my scripts/databases. I’m suprised there isn’t already built in support for bzip but the whirlpool library I can understand. This seems like the logical option as compared to rewriting work or paying more money for something I can fix myself or find.

http://www.gyrat.in/content/Whirlpool.java

translate it?
[/quote]

I almost have that one done. Im more concerned about the bzip2 impl.[/quote]https://github.com/koraktor/rbzip2

Read full topic
